mapsontheweb:

Voronoi Map of National Parks: the USA divided into regions based on which national park is closest

Source: wouj (reddit)

wouj:

I was thinking about the Voronoi diagram of state capitals thatâs been on here before, and it occurred to me that because national parks are often the destination of road trips, they would be a relatively useful subject for a Voronoi map. Hence, this submission!

One limitation: obviously, national parks are not point locations (there are nine states smaller than Wrangell-St. Elias NPâ¦) For the 59 points on this map, I just used the locations of the national park labels on Google Maps, which are all pretty centrally located. This simplification throws off the âtrueâ boundaries a little.

Edit: Many people are commenting about what does and doesnât count as a national park. Here is an excellent, detailed map of the whole U.S. park system: http://www.nps.gov/hfc/carto/PDF/NPSmap2.pdf My map includes the 59 things explicitly designated âNational Parkâ, which on that map includes anything ending in âNPâ or âNP & PRESâ. Yes there are many non-âNational Parkâs that are equally worth visiting, but thatâs a job for another map.

And as long as Iâm editing this post, three observations that struck me while I was making the map: 1. Itâs kind of ironic that Hot Springs âownsâ the largest âterritoryâ, since itâs the smallest park (and really doesnât fit in with the others in other respects - e.g. itâs located in an urban area). 2. I was genuinely shocked to learn that Isle Royale is the least visited national park in the lower 48, since I grew up in Minnesota where people talked about going there a lot! 3. I enjoy how Dry Tortugas, although itâs in Florida, manages to be the closest national park to nowhere in the continental US.
